headline.print_headline: So Big and Healthy Nowadays That Grandpa Wouldn’t Even Know You
headline.main: So Big and Healthy Grandpa Wouldn’t Even Know You

docs.lead_paragraph: The past 100 years has seen a change from small, sickly people to humans who are so robust their ancestors are almost unrecognizable.
docs.snippet: The past 100 years has seen a change from small, sickly people to humans who are so robust their ancestors are almost unrecognizable.

headline.print_headline: Living Large And Healthy, But How Long Can It Go On?
headline.main: Living Large and Healthy, but How Long Can It Go On?

docs.lead_paragraph: Longer life. Less disease. Less disability. The trends have continued for more than a century as humans have become bigger, stronger and healthier. But can they — will they — keep going? Or is there some countertrend, obesity or an overuse of medications, perhaps, that will turn the statistics around?.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three towering hickory trees in Milford, Conn., are the latest casualties of America’s lawsuit culture.
docs.snippet: Three towering hickory trees in Milford, Conn., are the latest casualties of America’s lawsuit culture.

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Common Good chairman Philip Howard says threat of lawsuits has taken hold of American society; questions propriety of decision by officials in Milford, Conn, to chop down hickory trees that grandmother Una Glennon said were threat to grandchild who was allergic to nuts and wanted to swim in her pool (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THREE towering hickory trees in neighboring Connecticut are the latest casualties of America's lawsuit culture. The particular trees, part of a group that line Wildemere Avenue in Milford, spread their branches over the back yard of Una Glennon, a grandmother of 14 who recently put in a pool for their enjoyment. Mrs. Glennon demanded that the trees be removed because one of her grandchildren is allergic to nuts and can't play in the pool with the other children when the nuts are falling. Earlier this month, the mayor of Milford announced that the trees would be chopped down: ''It really came down to taking a risk that child may be sick or even die.'' Mrs. Glennon said that she hoped the town would plant azaleas or ''something pretty.''
